comment.text: Also experienced the same WLAN issue as @hreindl
Those of you with the WLAN issue want to try the builds from https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=18418109 to make sure it is fixed before 4.10.4?  I would appreciate it.

besides that https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=18418109 has the same version and release tag which leads that you need "rpm -ivh --force" it don't change anything

[root@srv-rhsoft:~]$ crda
COUNTRY environment variable not set.
[root@srv-rhsoft:~]$ export COUNTRY=AT
[root@srv-rhsoft:~]$ crda
nl80211 not found.

- Works for me on Thinkpad X220 (Intel Core i5-2540M CPU @ 2.60GHz).
- Passed kernel regression tests and performance test completed in 8 minutes (performance tests were taking ~118 minutes in 4.9.x kernels).

- Works for me on Thinkpad X220 (Intel Core i5-2540M CPU @ 2.60GHz).
- Passed kernel regression tests; performance test completed in 8 minutes (performance tests were taking ~118 minutes in previous 4.9.x kernels).

Works here on x86_64 (T450s, Atom based server, VM).
Works fine on a x86_64 DO cloud instance, Raspberry Pi 2, Cubietruck, Beagebone Black

i get a NoVeau error when  booting the Kernel, apart from that it works , the error is

nouveau 0000:01:00.0: bus: MMIO read of 00000000 FAULT at 3e6684 [ IBUS ]
Booted on i7 desktop with nvidia card. Works.

looks like wireless and 4.10 is in a really bad shape and that said from sombody which as hostapd in use on Fedora for 5 years now and never faced any problems: https://forums.opensuse.org/showthread.php/523491-Kernel-4-10-x-setting-regulatory-domain-broken
Works on headless Dell R520.
No regressions noted on x86_64 Ivy Bridge or i686 Diamondville. However, I'm not giving +1 karma in solidarity with @hreindl and @psygnoser.

Just to note: with nouveau and "xset -dpms s off" in my .xinitrc, the screen no longer "wakes up" on keyboard input.  Not related to any suspend/resume.

Otherwise no issues.
wlan/hostapd/crda still broken - see https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1422247#c10 :-(
systemd-udevd[1487]: Process '/usr/sbin/crda' failed with exit code 251.

I get [these errors](https://paste.fedoraproject.org/paste/4-OPAieir5hED7NXkAzsZF5M1UNdIGYhyRLivL9gydE=) when building a larger C++ project (Ardour) in parallel. I guess it's still a case of [BZ#924570](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=924570).

I get the same CRDA problem as the previous commenters:

    Mar 21 10:42:18 gibraltar crda[1076]: setting regulatory domain to DE based on timezone (Europe/Berlin)
    …
    Mar 21 10:42:18 gibraltar systemd-udevd[890]: Process '/usr/sbin/crda' failed with exit code 251.
Oops. That went the wrong way.
CRDA broken
Oops, old habits die hard :)
Anyone care to test out module loading order on this kernel? https://forums.opensuse.org/showthread.php/523491-Kernel-4-10-x-setting-regulatory-domain-broken/page2 has some insight it seems.

yes, i would care when one with more insight would instruct me what to try - the link above is currently too low level given that a reboot don't make much fun on a machine driving your whole IT and has to supsend and wakeup several vritual machines at reboot

so when you give me something for /etc/modules-load.d/ which is suppose dot fix the issue i happily apply that and reboot the machine remote (not at home currently but i can test at least if CRDA works and hostapd.service starts as expected)
No regressions noted on x86_64 Ivy Bridge and i686 Diamondville. Not giving karma due to CRDA breakage.
Looks OK here on x86_64 (T450s, Atom based server, VM). Of course, this is just an info level +1, given all the problems already reported here.

Kernel 4.10.5 won't boot. When I revert back to 4.9.14 everything boots fine. I use Nvidia 378.13, i think they are causing problems.

How can I compile and install nvidia drivers for the 10.5 core when I can't even boot into it. Seems Fedora struggle a lot with recent kernel upgrades and nvidia....

1c

Message from syslogd@Bre at Mar 28 11:07:02 ...
kernel:mce: [Hardware Error]: PROCESSOR 0:306a9 TIME 1490710022 SOCKET 0 APIC 2 microcode
1c
dkms will not compile, and update nvidia 378.13 or 375.39.  fences.h seems to be missing. even trying to build nvidia driver without dkms fails. 4.9.14 works, not 4.10.5
http://rglinuxtech.com/ has some pointers to a patch for nvidia to get things working.

@anonymous: that's the price you have to pay when you mix 3rd-party-blobs and a fast moving distribution - the same happens here for vmware workstation regulary but Fedora is never the point of contact for that issues - in your case rpmfusion and pray to god is and one soltuion would be *not* switch to the next Fedora release until the used one is EOL

@hreindl, it was in the updates this morning. I had no reason to believe that dkms would puke, since all the 4.9 kernels updated 378.13 without problems.  I did use the patch, and now running 4.10.5-200 with 378.13 and no issues so far.

> I had no reason to believe that dkms would puke

you had - 4.9.x != 4.10.x 

when the first or second number in the version changes you have a new kernel generation which is supposed to break anything outside the upstream kernel tree (if not be happy but don't expect it)

@leigh123linux well, when he even combines Fedora with a handcrafted nivida driver instead using the rpmfusion ones it's pretty much expected that this setup will break regulary after each kernel update - there are at least people which can and do apply patches if available - however, it's expected that 3rd party kernel modules are breaking by jumping from 4.9 to 4.10 and the same will hapen in a few months from 4.10 to 4.11
karma: +1
running nice

bugs.title: CVE-2017-6874 kernel: Race condition in kernel/ucount.c

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2017-6874 kernel: Race condition in kernel/ucount.c

long_desc.thetext:
Race condition in kernel/ucount.c in the Linux kernel allows local users to cause a denial of service (use-after-free and system crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via crafted system calls that leverage certain decrement behavior that causes incorrect interaction between put_ucounts and get_ucounts.

Upstream patch:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=040757f738e13caaa9c5078bca79aa97e11dde88

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1432430]

Statement:

This issue did not affect the versions of the Linux kernel as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux and Red Hat Enterprise MRG as they did not include the vulnerable code.
kernel-4.9.17-100.fc24 has been pushed to the Fedora 24 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

bugs.title: CVE-2017-6874 kernel: Race condition in kernel/ucount.c [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2017-6874 kernel: Race condition in kernel/ucount.c [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2017-6874 kernel: Race condition in kernel/ucount.c

long_desc.thetext:
Race condition in kernel/ucount.c in the Linux kernel allows local users to cause a denial of service (use-after-free and system crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via crafted system calls that leverage certain decrement behavior that causes incorrect interaction between put_ucounts and get_ucounts.

Upstream patch:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=040757f738e13caaa9c5078bca79aa97e11dde88

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1432430]

Statement:

This issue did not affect the versions of the Linux kernel as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux and Red Hat Enterprise MRG as they did not include the vulnerable code.
kernel-4.9.17-100.fc24 has been pushed to the Fedora 24 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=1432429

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new
